text: Labour’s leader trolls 2 million people. Quite extraordinary.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: History is ALWAYS less harsh than the headlines. Journalism and history, journalists and historians, - not the same thing in so may good and bad ways
author: CharlieBeckett

text: You’re an intelligent person, that’s a bonkers thing to say. It’s a massive demo and they are reporting it just like they did, say, the Countryside Alliance marches. Calling it ‘propaganda’ is exactly the nasty, hyperbolic anti-journalism rhetoric that I’d hope you’d reject.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: It’s Sunday. But, if true, (and @ShippersUnbound is usually spot on) then all we need now is a snap election to make this the most ridiculously over-plotted political drama of all time.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: 'The world's biggest democracy' is about to launch into a vital election. If you haven't read it already, @jamescrabtree's Billionaire Raj is an engrossing and informative way into understanding this complex, compelling country #INDIA https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/554196/the-billionaire-raj-by-james-crabtree/9781524760069/ …
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Great to have so many brilliant women presenting but still clearly lacking real diversity at BBC flagship news shows
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Ecology?
author: CharlieBeckett

text: I’ve met so many more interesting people on the train
author: CharlieBeckett

text: An extraordinary woman who showed that philosophy - thousands of years after Plato etc - could be a practical, insightful and progressive way to re-imagine how we live and which policies we chose to shape our changing world
author: CharlieBeckett

text: This is like a game show.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Berlant’s Cruel Optimism was/is a mind-altering book for me. This excellent feature shows how it relates to everything from politics to love, Trump and, who knows, probably Brexit. It’s a challenging thesis, but as Berlant says ‘we refuse to be worn out’
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Good thread: a reminder that most MPs spend most of their time doing public service
author: CharlieBeckett

text: The only good thing about this story of government trying to hide the chaos that no-deal will bring is that I’m confident it will be all too apparent despite the gagging orders
author: CharlieBeckett

text: My pleasure. I think it's good to keep emphasising that while we talk as if each news org has a 'business model' they mostly have (or should have) a range of marketing/revenue strategies.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: If you are interested in getting curated quality news aggregated in a simple, personalised way, have a look at the @mogulnews start-up kickstarter offers https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/mogulnews/mogul-news-news-from-the-best-publishers-in-one-pl/description?ref=3dbtrs …
author: CharlieBeckett

text: It's never been tougher to find revenues for journalism which is why most news organisations are trying multiple methods. This is a useful survey of ways to make media pay from @damianradcliffe
author: CharlieBeckett

text: She speaks for the nation.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Upping this from Feb by @jeffjarvis because it is an outstanding and brutally honest survey of where we are at on a range of news media business model debates. TL/DR: lots of good changes happening but much more profound re-thinking needed
author: CharlieBeckett

text: BBC boss Tony Hall gave his vision for its future last night in a wide-ranging speech. All non-controversial and ambitious stuff. Interesting in the Q&A that he said that in terms of resources compared to its global rivals, his job is 'managing decline'. https://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/speeches/2019/tony-hall-lords …
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Sounds about right.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: And let me guess what your political stance is...it’s so boring: ‘She’s not saying what I want to hear...’
author: CharlieBeckett

text: From a different stance @JGForsyth is excellent
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Haha. I guess it depends on one’s political stance but I think people like @MattChorley and @GaryGibbonBlog are beacons of insight too.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Tonight, again @bbclaurak in absolutely scintillating form. She has an extraordinary ability to capture the drama while precisely narrating the chaos. We can argue about UK news media’s failure over the wider Brexit/Europe story but there’s been some outstanding coverage.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Whatever a ‘cheese and biscuit circuit’ is, I want to join.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Parody account stuff.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: This is superb instant history on Brexit. I know we are all caught up in the chaos of the moment but this is v useful context. I was talking to John Birt about this tonight - ‘the mission to explain’ is more vital than ever
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Cometh the hour, cometh the incredible pathetic politician.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Thoughtful and perceptive from @emilybell on lessons for all kinds of media - and society - from the New Zealand terror attack. https://www.cjr.org/tow_center/facebook-twitter-christchurch-emily-bell-terrorism.php … via @cjr
author: CharlieBeckett

text: It would be impossible to list all the evidence of UK government falling apart. This is just another relatively small one. No 10 can't even announce their own PM's emergency speeches.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: What a lovely story of social media at its less good and then rather better. For once a tale of a virtuous viral cycle. https://www.buzzfeed.com/adeonibada/man-making-ice-cream-meme?utm_source=dynamic&utm_campaign=bfsharetwitter … via @SincerelyAde
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Apart from some kind of catharsis, what would it achieve if its contested by the same two parties with the same policies, divisions, fantasies and contradictions as they have now?
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Very cool traditional sleuthing from @telegraphnews
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Same govt that took £745 m out of BBC for over 75 licence fees
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Not sure I want government to support it.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Also, will it focus on new, innovative, organic forms of journalism or will it get sucked into filling the gaps left by traditional local news?
author: CharlieBeckett

text: A much-needed boost for local journalism. Obviously, anything like this that depends on the BBC and the tech companies has powerful backers but can it create  independent, diverse, sustainable journalism?
author: CharlieBeckett

text: @millerC4 great film tonight from NZ.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Glad to see the blog on coverage of the Ethiopia plane crash by my student @behailus get picked up by #aljazeera
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Fascinating animated data viz of changing ranking of world cities since 1500.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: I don’t think I’m the core demographic for #fleabag but it is the best thing in so many ways. Writing, filming, acting, at a different level.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: BBC lunchtime radio news ran this story as their ‘light’ end of bulletin item. Which says everything about the dire state of the UK/world right now.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Luke 15.10
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Quite right.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Perhaps also stop calling him ‘the shooter’ it’s such a neutral term - he is the killer/terrorist/murderer
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Politics in Britain has turned into some kind of 1960s Czech avant- garde protest movie.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Both UK parties are indulging in a kind of ideological ethnic cleansing. It’s utterly self destructive. The whole point of mainstream parties is that they are coalitions.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: One of the best reactive policy decisions was Uk tightening up of gun laws after Dunblane. US is exceptional.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Posh click bait
author: CharlieBeckett

text: And mainstream media’s role in providing the anti-Islamic condition and the amplification for extremist messages? (Not @Channel4News obviously)
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Critical thinking
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Sorry to repeat what everyone else is saying but the ripper did have a feedback loop: newspapers. Things are different now but we shouldn’t treat social media as some kind of new magic or curse
author: CharlieBeckett

text: What a bonkers match. Apologies to Huddersfield supporters for getting your hopes up. We get that most weeks.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: That's right. Which makes it even more important for news media not to accept his framing of the narrative. All terrorists try to play the media, this one even more than most.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Lots of reaction on my social media about the reporting of the appalling attacks in New Zealand. I've written something with my first thoughts on the coverage and lessons to be learnt....
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Reporting Terror: here are some first thoughts from me on the issues raised by the media coverage of the terror attack in Christchurch, New Zealand. It's based on a report I wrote on covering terror events that you might find relevant. https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/polis/2019/03/16/reporting-terror-first-lessons-from-new-zealand/ … via @PolisLSE
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Interesting. It seems viral fakes after terror events only work in a fact vacuum:  ‘the shooter’s media plan was so comprehensive, and his content spread so quickly, that there was little room for fakes to fill the void’
author: CharlieBeckett

text: One of my students, an Ethiopian communications expert, writes about the media representation of the ET302 crash and suggests it is symptomatic of a wider problem about Western representations of news out of 'Africa.' https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/polis/2019/03/15/from-africanising-the-crash-to-ethiopianising-the-problem-the-media-representation-of-the-et302-crash-is-symptomatic-of-a-wider-problem/ … via @PolisLSE
author: CharlieBeckett

text: And example of better media behaviour - correcting a mistake made in haste. Obviously better not to have done it at all.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: This was a report I wrote on the challenges of reporting on terror events. Most still relevant. Good to see some better behaviour by authorities and some media. Platforms still struggling... #Christchurch  http://www.lse.ac.uk/media@lse/documents/Reporting-on-Terror-in-a-Networked-World-(Beckett).pdf …
author: CharlieBeckett

text: At a time like this it pays not to leap to judgements. This is a useful guide on how not to do that #Christchurch
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Paul Gilroy's Ain't No Black In The Union Jack was a massive mind-opener for me back in the 1980s. Great to see him getting this backing now and inspiring to note his (relative) optimism https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/paul-gilroy-academy-taking-race-seriously-last … via @timeshighered
author: CharlieBeckett

text: And a podcast producer role
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Two great jobs going at @TheEconomist in their innovative digital team: Social media fellowship
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Leadership
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Agree. Politics is the art of the possible, it's not a war of mutually assured destruction.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: A wider take: "If the EU is an empire then it is exceptional in being a legally voluntary empire...it is this peculiar characteristic of the EU’s ‘liberal empire’ that explains the tortured political process in Britain following the Brexit referendum"
author: CharlieBeckett

text: How the news finds you. Weird and wonderful (and somehow significant?) thread.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: I have a theory that they do it because they are aware of their personal Remain predilections and so think Leave voices need extra explaining but it ends up as both cursory, patronising and unbalanced #BBC #newsnight #brexit
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Blimey #newsnight I’m starting to believe Remainer conspiracy theories: yet another BBC film asking what people in core Leave areas think about Brexit. Have you any examples of films about Remain grass roots?
author: CharlieBeckett

text: People love voice but they are not using it for news: huge challenge for journalism to get across a major new platform/portal. Check out @nicnewman’s prez to #HHLDN
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Great presentation on how to build better news graphics but also how to spread learning #HHldn
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Had this conversation y'day. Journalists instinctively (and not wrongly) hate marketing as a 'threat' to editorial independence. But if marketing means 'getting people to consume your content' then surely that's a core value? What's the point of journalism without an audience?
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Never mind the senseless roller coaster ride of Brexit, can I face another year of the dashed hopes and false dawns of #WHUFC? Remain or leave?
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Whatever else today signifies, this is a glorious triumph of the theatre of politics and media over substance. #Brexit
author: CharlieBeckett

text: "Future made in Europe": a remarkably positive, realistic strategic vision for the EU from the next leader of Germany.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: If you need one summary of where the UK parliament is at on #Brexit and what is at stake in advance of Tuesday's vote then this by @andrewrawnsley  is as good as I've read
author: CharlieBeckett

text: The replies to this make for an interesting thread on how Facebook's recently-declared strategy shift to more closed, 'private' conversations might impact on news publishers' engagement. Will it impact on the reach and attention for journalism content?
author: CharlieBeckett

text: This is a beautiful book, full of outstanding short stories. An exquisite and varied selection of a rich literary culture. #Italy https://www.penguin.co.uk/books/304/304873/the-penguin-book-of-italian-short-stories/9780241299838.html …
author: CharlieBeckett

text: This is a neat visualisation of some interesting research suggesting that Trump’s populism is scripted.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: These are all good questions to which I suspect Facebook hasn’t yet worked out the answers.
author: CharlieBeckett

text:
Interesting thread on distribution of Leave and Remain voters that suggests at least one reason why the latter may not understand the former 
(HT @rcolvile)
author: CharlieBeckett

text: The idea of a 'civilization state' is an interesting way to think about how some countries are redefining the idea of national ideologies. Not great news for liberal democracy... #China #India #Trump https://www.ft.com/content/b6bc9ac2-3e5b-11e9-9bee-efab61506f44 … via @financialtimes
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Until Joanna Hogg makes another movie we have #Fleabag
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Not ideal for a fun Friday film but when you are in the mood for a stunning movie about loss, pain, war, love, history and memory, this is it. Strangely funny and joyful amidst the agony....
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Are we heading towards a digital dystopia? Listen to our recent debate at the LSE with @byers90 @lynskeyo @a_b_powell #LSEFestival #NewWorldDisorders #LSEt3
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Forget Momo challenge, this is a real threat of online harm: predictive algorithms in digital public services
author: CharlieBeckett

text: In our LSE Truth Trust and Technology Commission report we propose an Independent Platform Agency that could gather and inspect this kind of data. http://www.lse.ac.uk/media-and-communications/assets/documents/research/T3-Report-Tackling-the-Information-Crisis-v6.pdf … #LSEt3
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Excellent article on moral panics around online harm that makes the v good point that we need much better data from the tech companies before we act: "government should..create statutory information-gathering powers to give regulators access to detailed, anonymised data' #LSEt3
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Congrats to @bendepear and the fabulous @Channel4News team for proving that determined original journalism is still vital and thriving in TV newsrooms. Have to admit it’s improved since I was there...
author: CharlieBeckett

text: My fascination with TikTok increases...
author: CharlieBeckett

text: I haven't quite worked out a journalism studies angle on this yet, but TikTok is clearly fascinating in terms of UX, audience engagement and funding/biz model.
author: CharlieBeckett

text:
See also:
'I am part of a reflective, self-critical, intellectual community; you are subject to confirmation bias; they are in a filter bubble'.
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Really good event - thanks to the brilliant panel and great audience questions
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Look forward to seeing you Owen
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Never mind the Internet, TV is still where the public get most key political information, especially about new parties and especially for ‘inattentive’ demographics according to this new research on last Spanish elections
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Digital optimist or pessimist?
author: CharlieBeckett

text: More proof that apps and gamification works brilliantly for social and political control in the right context
author: CharlieBeckett

text: For those interested in the DCMS Facebook digital regulation story, here’s the recent LSE policy report on how we should tackle the information crisis in a systematic way
author: CharlieBeckett

text: Sounds dreadful tbh Carl.
author: CharlieBeckett
